title: Study of the Morphological and Surface Properties of Silica Dioxide Nanoparticles for Their Potential Use in Biomedical Applications
content: Silica dioxide (SiO2) nanoparticles have attracted great interest in recent years due to their unique properties and potential diverse applications. One of the most widely used methods for synthesizing SiO2 nanoparticles is the St√∂ber method, developed in 1968 [1]. This method involves the hydrolysis and condensation of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) in a solution of ethanol and ammoniacal water. The reactions can be carefully controlled to produce monodisperse nanoparticles with tunable sizes between 50-2000 nm. The importance of the synthesis method is reflected in the various properties that these particles can acquire. These different synthesis routes (thermal, sol-gel, precipitation, etc.) provide us with the necessary variants for the diverse biomedical applications [2].
